data.title: Former teammates at B.C. school 'flabbergasted' by reports Calgary man joined terrorists in Syria
data.meta_description: Gregory Gordon, one of two brothers who allegedly travelled to Syria to join the Islamic State, grew up in Calgary
data.text:
One of two brothers from Calgary who reportedly travelled overseas to join a terrorist group in Syria was a quiet but social young man who didn't talk about religion during a short time playing volleyball at a British Columbia university, say people who knew him at the time.

CBC News reported last week that Collin and Gregory Gordon, two brothers who most recently lived in Calgary, had travelled to Syria to join the Islamic State.

Collin Gordon, who grew up in Calgary and played volleyball for the Southern Alberta Institute of Technology, joined the WolfPack men's volleyball team at Thompson Rivers University in Kamloops, B.C., in 2008. He dropped out of school the following year.

In a university media package prepared for the 2008-09 WolfPack season, Mr. Gordon is described as an average volleyball player who had good ball control and an excellent vertical jump.

Mr. Gordon is quoted in the media package as saying his biggest role model was swimmer Michael Phelps, whom he described as "the example of perfection." He said his long-term goals included operating a small business.

Spencer Reed, who was in his first year on the team that season, said Mr. Gordon was a "mellow dude" who was known for throwing parties.

"He just sort of went about his own business," Mr. Reed told Kamloops This Week.

"He was quite well known in the campus community, I think. He was involved in a lot of little projects, quite social, just sort of did things he was interested in." Reed said he was stunned when he saw a photo of Mr. Gordon accompanying the CBC story about the brothers. Reed sent text messages to other former teammates, all of whom were "flabbergasted," he said.

Mr. Reed said he and Mr. Gordon got along, but they weren't especially close. He never knew Mr. Gordon to speak about religion.

"It never came out," Mr. Reed said.

After Mr. Gordon dropped out of Thompson Rivers University, he was active in a group called the Kamloops Social Club, which organized parties at local bars.

"He was an interesting character," said Nate Froese, who operates Joy Factory Films and did some work for the social club.

"He was very driven and ambitious, but he had a hard time following through on things. He had goals in mind and he went after them, that's for sure." A Twitter account that purports to belong to Mr. Gordon was filled primarily with posts about basketball games and weekend plans in 2011, when, at least for part of that year, he appeared to still be living in Kamloops.

The tone began to shift in early 2012, when Mr. Gordon interspersed his postings with quotes from the Koran. By May, 2012, his Twitter feed was almost exclusively devoted to religion.

Kamloops This Week attempted to reach Mr. Gordon by sending him messages on social media.

He declined an interview, instead writing: "I will consult with my brothers as Allah says to do and then make a decision in your regard." When asked whether the allegations against him are true, he wrote: "You would find the truth in the Qur'an."
